question.content: Who among the following leaders led the Revolt of 1857 in Bihar?

question.content: From which place did the Revolt of 1857 start?

solution.content: Meerut (10 May 1857). The Revolt of 1857 Also called Sepoy Mutiny (By the British Historians), First War of Independence (by Vinayak Damodar Savarkar). Lord Canning was the British Governor general during the revolt.

question.content: During British rule in India, which of the following Governor Generals devised the 'Doctrine of Lapse', a policy of annexation?

solution.content: Lord Dalhousie was the Governor-General from 1848 to 1856. The doctrine declared that if an Indian ruler died without a male heir his kingdom would "lapse", that is, become part of Company territory. States annexed under Doctrine of lapse: Satara (1848), Sambalpur (1850), Udaipur (1852), Nagpur (1853), Jhansi (1854) and Awadh (1856).

question.content: When was the Defence of India Act enacted?

solution.content: 1915. The Defence of India Act (1915) It was an emergency law that gave the British government in India wide powers to suppress dissent and maintain public order during World War I. It was passed by the then Governor General of India Lord Hardinge.

question.content: Which Act declared that British rule in India would end by 30 June 1948?

solution.content: Act of 1947. The Indian Independence Act 1947 was an Act of Parliament of the United Kingdom that granted independence to British India. The Act was passed on July 18, 1947, and came into effect on August 15, 1947. The Act divided British India into two independent dominions, India and Pakistan.

question.content: In India which Act divided the powers between the Central and units in terms of three lists?

solution.content: 1935. Government of India Act, 1935: Contain three lists, Federal List (for Centre containing 59 items), Provincial List (for provinces containing 54 items) and the Concurrent List (for both containing 36 items). The seventh schedule (Article 246) deals with the division of powers between the union and the states.

question.content: From which places did Lord Cornwallis start the permanent settlement system?

solution.content: Bengal and Bihar. Provision of Permanent Settlement (Introduced in 1793 AD) The owners of the land were known as landlords or Zamindars, Hereditary rights of succession of the lands under them were granted to them, The sum which the landlords had to pay was fixed, The Zamindars could sell or transfer the land as they wished. question.content: In which of the following years did the East India Company abolish the diarchy system of Bengal?

solution.content: 1772. The system of Dual Government: Introduced in Bengal by Robert Clive of British East India Company. It lasted from 1765 to 1772. Under this system, the administration of Bengal was divided into Nizamat and Diwani. The Diwani was carried out by the company and the Nizamat by the Nizam.

question.content: Ryotwari system of revenue collection in India, introduced by the British, was based onthe

solution.content: Ricardian theory of rent The land of higher fertility gets higher rent than less fertile land. Ryotwari System The peasants or cultivators were regarded as the owners of the land. The cultivators had to pay annual taxes directly to the government. Introduced by Thomas Munro and Alexander Read in 1820 in the Madras and Bombay presidency. Mahalwari system - The land revenue was collected from the farmers by the village headmen on behalf of the whole village. Introduced by Holt Mackenzie in 1822 in areas of Uttar Pradesh.

question.content: With which of the following Government of India Acts did the Montagu-Chelmsford Reforms introduce Dyarchy in the provinces?

question.content: When was a comprehensive despatch on education called Wood's despatch on education sent?

solution.content: 1854. Charles Wood (the President of the Board of Control) sent a despatch to Lord Dalhousie (Governor-General of India). It suggested introducing vernacular languages in the primary schools of India, high schools use anglo-vernacular mediums and that English should be the medium for college-level education. Hence, the Wood's Despatch is considered as 'Magna-Carta' of English Education in India. Wood's despatch led to the establishment of the first three universities in 1857, at Calcutta, Bombay and Madras. question.content: Which act was passed by the British Government of India to introduce provincial autonomy?

question.content: The Pitts India Act of distinguished between the commercial and political functions of the British East India Company.

solution.content: Pitt's India Act, 1784 established the dual system of control by the British government and the East India Company. The Company became a subordinate department of the State and its territories in India were termed 'British possessions'. In this act members of the Executive Council were reduced to 3, and the Governor-General served as its commander in chief.

question.content: The bill which provide for the trial of British or European person by Indians magistrates was

question.content: Which of the following Indian states was the first to sign a subsidiary alliance with the British?

question.content: What is the original name of the Empress of India Act and when was it instituted?

solution.content: Rabindranath Tagore. Visvabharati university was founded by Rabindranath Tagore. Bangadarshan magazine was edited by Rabindranath Tagore.

question.content: Who used the ancient texts to suggest that widows could remarry?

solution.content: Ishwar Chandra Vidyasagar's efforts, the then Government of India passed the Widow Remarriage Act in 1856. He also raised concern for the abolition of child marriage and polygamy. He supported Bethune to establish the first permanent girls' school in India, the Bethune School.

question.content: Which freedom fighter of India composed the song, 'Saare Jahan Se Achha'?

solution.content: Mohammad Iqbal. The song is also referred to as 'Taranah-e-Hindi'. The poem was published in the weekly journal Ittehad on August 16, 1904.

question.content: Who among the following was popularly known as 'Gurudev' for his expertise in binding together elements of Indian classical music and folk pieces to suit the western tunes entailed with precision along with his expertise in other art domains?

solution.content: Rabindranath Tagore. He won the Nobel Prize in literature for "Gitanjali" in 1913. He was First Non-European to Win a Nobel Literature Prize. Rabindranath Tagore is mostly renowned as the "Bard of Bengal". Some Literary works by him are Chokher bali, The Postmaster, Gora, Kabuliwala (The Fruitseller from Kabul), 1961, Sadhana.

question.content: On 21 October 1943, Subhash Chandra Bose proclaimed the formation of the Provisional Government of Free India in

solution.content: Singapore. The All India Forward Bloc was founded by Subhash Chandra Bose. He founded the Azad Hind Government on 21st October 1943.

question.content: Who among the following Indian freedom fighters was fondly called Gandhi Buri (Old Lady Gandhi) for her dedication towards Gandhian principles?

solution.content: Matangini Hazra. Matangini Hazra was an Indian revolutionary and social activist who participated in the Indian independence movement.

question.content: Avadh Kisan Sabha was set up in the year

solution.content: 1920. Oudh Kisan Sabha (Oudh Farmers Association) was an association formed by Baba Ram Chandra. He was a trade unionist who organized the farmers of Oudh and led the first protest against the landlords.

question.content: India and Pakistan had signed the _, under which the two countries agreed to sort out differences and disputes bilaterally.

solution.content: Shimla Pact was signed in 1972 by Zulfiqar Ali Bhutto, the President of Pakistan, and Indira Gandhi, the Prime Minister of India.

question.content: What was the name of the operation that led to the annexation of the Hyderabad State into India?

solution.content: Operation Polo - the code name of the Hyderabad "police action" in September 1948. It was a military operation in which the Indian Armed Forces invaded the Nizam-ruled princely state, annexing it into the Indian Union.

question.content: Which one of the following is not one of the writings of Lala Lajpat Rai?

solution.content: "India wins freedom" is the Autobiography of Maulana Abul Kalam Azad.

question.content: With whom is the 'Patharughat Uprising' associated?  Lawyers' uprising (b) Soldiers' uprising (c) Teachers' uprising (d) Peasants' uprising (Morning)

solution.content: Peasants' uprising. It was against the tax policies of the British in 1894. Patharughat is a place in Assam and is currently known as Patharighat.

question.content: Who among the following was a freedom fighter, based on whose design the present Indian National Flag is designed?

solution.content: Pingali Venkaiah. The design of the National Flag was adopted by the Constituent Assembly of India on 22 July 1947. The ratio of width of the flag to its length is two to three.

question.content: The _ movement was led by Chaudhary Devi Lal in 1987.

solution.content: Nyaya Yudh.He founded the Lok Dal party.

question.content: Chandernagore (Chandannagar) wasa colony captured by the British Navy on 23 March 1757.

solution.content: French. Battle of Chandernagore (1757) - Between French and British (led by Robert Clive) during the Seven Years' War (1756-1763).

question.content: In which of the following years did Japan invade India resulting in the Battle of Imphal?

solution.content: 1944. The outcome of the battle of Imphal was a turning point of one of the most gruelling campaigns of the Second World War (1939-45).

question.content: In which of the following years was the Bombay Reorganization Act passed?

solution.content: 1960. After this act, Bombay State was dissolved and split on linguistic lines into the two states of Gujarat (Gujarati speaking population) and Maharashtra (Marathi speaking population).

question.content: Who among the following is one of the founder members of Bhartiya Jana Sangh?

solution.content: Shyama Prasad Mukherjee. BJS was an Indian right-wing political party that existed from 1951 to 1977 and was the political arm of Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS), a Hindu nationalist volunteer organization.

question.content: A large area of land demarcated as Damin-i-Koh in 1832 was declared as the land of the

solution.content: Santhals (Tribal who inhabited the forest of Rajmahal hills). Damin-i-Koh British promised non-interference in the land.

question.content: Fort Saint Louis was a _ fort that stood in Pondicherry on the eastern coast of India.

solution.content: French. Fort Saint Louis Built by Francois Martin and Destroyed by the Britishers in 1761. First French factory Surat, Gujrat (1668). Forts of British - Fort William (Calcutta), Fort St. George (Madrass).

question.content: What was the meaning of 'Ryot' in British records in the 18th century?

solution.content: Peasants. Ryots were Individual cultivators who had full rights regarding sale, transfer, and leasing of the land as long as they paid the rent under the Ryotwari system (Land revenue paid by the farmers directly to the state).

question.content: Who was the Nawab of Bhopal that ruled from 1868 to 1901?

solution.content: Shah Jahan Begum. Nawab of Bhopal that ruled - Nawab Sikandar Begum:- 1860-1868, Begum Sultan Shah Jehan:-1844-1860 and 1868-1901. Begum Kaikhusrau Jahan:- 1901-1926, Begum Sajida Sultan:- 1961-1995.

question.content: Who among the following was one of the speakers after Jawaharlal Nehru to address the Parliament on the midnight of 15 August 1947?

solution.content: Dr. Sarvepalli Radhakrishan (1st Vice President of India) was one of the three main speakers at the Central Hall of Parliament - other than JL Nehru (Tryst with Destiny Speech) and Chaudhary Khaliquzaman.

question.content: The princely state of Hyderabad was brought under the Indian Union in the year_

solution.content: 1948. After the State Reorganisation Act 1956 Hyderabad was merged with Andhra state and later renamed as Andhra Pradesh.

question.content: Who was the chairman of the Economic Programme Committee (EPC) that was formed by the All India Congress Committee in 1947?

solution.content: Jawaharlal Nehru. The aim of this committee was to make a plan which could balance private and public partnership and urban and rural economies.

question.content: In which of the following cities is the tomb of Rani of Jhansi situated?

solution.content: Gwalior. The Samadhi of Rani Lakshmi Bai is situated at Phool Bagh. It is to commemorate the great warrior of Jhansi. Rani Lakshmi Bai, fought the battle against the British Raj during the Indian rebellion of 1857.

question.content: Which leader gave us the C-R Formula?

solution.content: Rajagopalachari's formula (or C. R. formula or Rajaji formula) was a proposal formulated by Chakravarti Rajagopalachari to solve the political deadlock between the All India Muslim League and the Indian National Congress on the independence of British India.

question.content: _ was awarded the Nobel Prize in 1913 and a knighthood in 1915.

solution.content: Rabindranath Tagore became the first non-European to receive the Nobel Prize for his literary work. He was awarded knighthood in 1915 by King George V.
